title: 180mm fan duct adapter to 4" or 100mm pvc ventilation tube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this to adapt a 180mm computer fan to a 100mm pvc pipe to allow better airflow in my printer shed.

Update 01.sept 2017

Piece came out very rigid and i printed it in clear PLA so that its easier to study the pictures and structure.

Please note that the internal diameter is 100mm and not 105mm measure your pipe before assembly and if you need a bigger hole send me a comment.

If you print this and cant fit it . Boil some water and dip the end into the water to soften the PLA, then while still being softened work it around the tube.

This may also be used with flexible duct hose .

author: Sam31

print_settings.Notes:: Das Filament PETG - Ruby Red

description.text:
This is a bird house designed to look like a traditional Swedish cottage with a small front porch.

You can decide if you want to print the house shell as one piece:

  • gehaeuse_v2

or you can print the house shell in 3 parts:

  • Floor: boden_v2
  • Sidewall 1: fasssade_01
  • Sidewall 2: fasssade_02_v2

There are also two mounting plates for the house available:

  • montageleiste | for screw mounting (M6 or similar)
  • montageleiste_2 | for zip tie, wire or string mounting

What you need:

  • Patience ( My printing time was ~100h)
  • Super Glue
  • A drinking straw (5mm Outer Diameter) for the roof gutter
  • A M6 Screw and nut or something similar to mount the birdhouse to the mounting braket
  • 4 M5 Nuts and 4 Screws for the detachable roof
  • I also use black nail polish and painted the surface for the window and door opening black before i glued the parts to the house.

Printer:

Hypercube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Bird house was printed with the following Materials:

  1. Das Filament PETG - Ruby Red
  2. Polymaker PolyMax - White
  3. 3D Multimode PETG (cheap ebay stuff) - Black

On the digital clock versions of these ovens you have 6 of these buttons, if you break or lose one this should do the trick.  
Under instructions I have some tips on getting a good result on this small part

As it is a very small part you will need to either print more than 1 to allow the layer to cool or in my case using slic3r under the Printer Settings ==> Extruder 1 I have
Retraction
--Length 2
--Lift Z 5 mm
--Speed 30 mm
--Minimum travel after retraction 2 mm This causes the Extruder to lift and drop between layers giving enough time to cool the layer. I'm also running a large fan :) Depending on your final result you might need to sand the end a little to reduce its radius so it doesn't stick when you push it in.

description.text:
Hi!

Give your kitchen a 3DPrinter style!

Here you got some nozzle-like shakers for salt and pepper, oregano and other spices.

And one heatsink stand

Files:

Nozzles

  • saltpepper_nozzle.stl: Small holes
  • oregano_nozzle.stl: big holes for other spices
  • 1hole_nozzle.stl: One single hole (like a real nozzle)
  • NoHolesNozzle.stl: No holes, you can use as a bottle

Screws

  • screw.stl: The screw
  • screw_vasemode.stl: Useful for printing in vasemode

Stand

  • stand_heatsink.stl: Heat sink-like stand for two shakers

The screws have tolerances to print without tweaking in the slicer. For this shakers it's better a smooth or loose fit.

Of course, OpenSCAD code included.

Hope you find it useful
Have fun!

ANET E10

Printed with the ANET E10 using PLA.

I recommend printing the screw in some translucent PLA or PETG using vasemode with 1 shell. My tips for vasemode: Reduce speed and increase flow.

You can buy ANET E10 here: EU PLUG | US PLUG | UK PLUG

description.text:
Update Oct 22, 2017: Added MexicanTrainBoxTopThin.stl which is a looser fit and is easier to remove than the other one. Also added MexicanTrainBox3mm.stl which is sturdier and has 3mm walls.

This is a Mexican Train set that includes everything except the dominoes. The set includes optional skins which greatly reduce the noise made when shuffling the dominoes. People with sensitive hearing (especially those with hearing aids) can be greatly annoyed by the shuffling noise. The skins are made with flexible filament (I used TPU) and are designed to fit a popular double twelve, 91 piece, domino set, such as: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00004T71M/ .

The scoresheets are printed two-up on a sheet of paper. To make a scorepad, you can trim a stack of sheets so they are the same size. Place a weight on top of the pad so the top edge is exposed. Brush Elmer's glue on the edge. When the glue dries you will have a nice scorepad that will fit in the Mexican Train box.

The box is designed to hold the dominoes with skins and has room for the scorepad on top of the dominoes. The tray holds the center console and steam engine and sombrero pieces and has room for a mechanical pencil to rest on top.

Dar der Stepper beim spannen des Riemens enorm belastet wird und sich die Position ändert, habe ich dieses Stützlager entworfen. title: PanoBot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
PANOBOT: A Panorama robot, version 1

Panobot is a full automatic robot, which can be used to create Panoramas and Gigapixels with small and large cameras (like DSLRs). The camera is mounted on a turret to allow pan/tilt motion. After programming the capture parameters, the robot will start to rotate the camera, taking one (or multiple) pictures per position and making sure that the capture positions have enough overlap.

This is a Panorama Robot created to hold large cameras, like DSLRs, with big telephoto lenses. I'm using this bot to create panoramas and Gigapixels with my Canon 80D DSLR and have used lenses up to 600mm.

Panobot has the following menu features:

  • Scan
    • starts a Scan
  • Sphere
    • starts a 360x180 scan
  • Take picture
    • allows to manually take a picture, this is usefull for testing the camera trigger connection
  • Setup
    • Pan Left, Pan Right, Tilt Up, Tilt Down
      • defines the scan area of the panorama/gigapixel, the head will move while the range is defined
    • Image P-Delay
      • the longer, the more time the camera has to measure and (eventually focus, if not in manual camera mode), triggers focusing of camera
    • Image Delay
      • the delay it take for the camera to write the image to the card and/or the time it needs to stabilize the mechanical system due to rotating motion
    • Shutter Delay
      • how long the shutter will be pressed
    • Focal Length
      • the focal length which is currently by the camera
    • Horizontal& Vertical Overlap
      • defines the overlap between consecutive images, a value between 30% and 50% makes sense, usually depends on the capture situation
    • Crop factor
      • in combination with the focal length, can be used to calculate field of view, which is required for horizontal&vertical overlap

Required Hardware:

  • 3d printed parts
    • 1 central_gear
    • print a mount for your tripod, this connects central gear and tripod - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764632
    • 1 drivegear
    • 1 central_pan_print
    • 1 stepper_pan_mount_print
    • 2 pantiltconnector_print
    • 2 tiltsteppermount_print
    • 1tiltsidesteppergear
    • 1tiltsidedrivegear
    • 1tiltside
    • 1tiltsidedrive
    • print 1x panobot_tilt_spacer.stl
    • print a case for the LCD - go to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250 and print the following parts:
      • 1x https://www.thingiverse.com/download:195365 (Bottom Case with Pockets)
      • 1x https://www.thingiverse.com/download:195366 (Top Case)
      • 1x https://www.thingiverse.com/download:195440 (Controller Knob)
      • 1x https://www.thingiverse.com/download:887992 (Kill Button)
      • 1x panobot-lcd-clamp.stl (2 parts inside)
    • print the case for the panobot electronic
      • print 1x electronic-case-bottom.stl
      • print 1x electronic-case-top-4040fan.stl xor 1x electronic_case_top-5050fan.stl
      • print 1x electronic-case-pcb-clamps.stl (3 parts inside the stl)
    • print a mount for your camera, choose one of the two variants
      • variant 1:
        • print 1x camquickmount.stl
        • print 2x quickmountclamp.stl
      • variant 2 (better, improved version):
        • print 1x panobot_tilt_base_mount.stl
      • I also recommend to buy one of these mounts Camera Tripod Aluminum Quick Release Plate, which fit nicely on the printed mounts

  • mechanical parts

    • some screws, washers, nuts M3, M4
    • some bearings 608
    • rods 8mm ( Pan: 2x210mm, Tilt: 2x200mm, Pan/Tilt: 4x120mm)
  • electronic parts
    • a complete list of required parts and instructions can be found on Panobot Github Wiki

Required Software:

  • install atom editor
    • https://atom.io/ -> install deb
  • follow steps on http://platformio.org/get-started/ide?install=atom
    • install platformio-ide package inside atom
  • code completion
    • apt-get install clang

Everything can be found in my github Repository: http://github.com/RobertFach/panobot.git

Finally, here are some examples of the panoramas that I have created with this machine:

  • http://www.gigapan.com/gigapans/201613 (1.2 Gigapixel)
  • http://www.gigapan.com/gigapans/201533 (360 degree, 400 Megapixel)
  • http://www.gigapan.com/gigapans/201669 (360x180degree spherical image, 300 Megapixel)

An this is a video of a running capture... https://vimeo.com/231263998 (The video shows an early version. The current version takes the pictures much faster and is easier to build.)

UPDATE:

19/02/2018

  • added some spacers for the tilt axis
  • added more pictures about the electronics and the new mount

18/02/2018

  • added an improved version of the camera mount (panobot_tilt_base_mount.stl), this version reduces the footprint of the camera mount itself and replace camquickmount.stl and quickmountclamp.stl

17/02/2018

  • added electronic case for the Panobot electronics
  • removed deprecated pictures of the prototype pcb
  • added link to lcd case and added a special clamp to mount lcd to panobot frame

04/02/2018

  • added a link to the customizable panobot tripod mount generator on thingiverse

24/01/2018

  • added some pictures about connecting panbase to central gear. You can either choose a bolt with 8mm or use a screw M8x60, washers and nuts. The same applies to tiltbase.

20/01/2018

  • added a complete BOM for the electronic parts which can be found on github

19/01/2018

  • removed CNC Shield Expansion Board A4988 Driver For Arduino, no longer required for the bot itself, however, it can be used for upcoming extensions

16/01/2018

  • PCB tests okay, let me know if you need one. Some tutorials for assembling the electronic parts are in work.

11/01/2018

  • PCBs arrived, also working on USB code and a slider extension

23/12/2017

  • Updated the github repository. Added the pcb layout and updated schematic. Also added the spherical scan mode, to create 360x180 panospheres.

21/12/2017

  • Good news, the PCB is ready and a batch of ten boards has been ordered. Send me a message if you want to get one. Beside that, there is also progress with the firmware.

08/12/2017

  • testing the new pcb assembly, it stacks on top of Arduino Mega and USB Hostshield, have a look at the pictures. Please let me know if you have interest in a pcb, the more we are, the cheaper it gets...

03/11/2017

  • please provide Feedback if you want to get a pcb for Panobot...

29/10/2017

  • added schematic for electronic components

19/10/2017

  • added some links to required electronic parts

16/09/2017

  • published firmware on http://github.com/RobertFach/panobot.git

09/09/2017

  • arranged some of the STL models ready for printing, files have been added and print instruction has been updated
  • pcb and firmware for version 1 will be released soon
  • added picture of version 2 prototype of the electronics + bot extensions, V2 will be able to use USB to connect to camera (PTP models) or remote cable shutter, will use Smart Full Graphic LCD with clickencoder, will use a GPS for GEO tagging the pictures, and more :)

author: PI3D

title: Quadcopter JK_Groß
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My first DIY Quadcopter frame after crashing my original Quad one time to often.
I designed it to not need support but the frame parts are a bit challenging.
I flew it with a 4S 10000mAh Multistar Battery from hobbyking.
Motors and ESCs are from a LD-Power LD 300 I think but every other 10 inch Motor system should work fine.
My Quad with FPV weight around 1.7kg so its incredible heavy but its nice and stable but thanks to the low profile design also very fast.

For the main frame I used 15mm square aluminum tube but maybe I will test it with wood.
The frame parts are completely interchangeable so you can just drill another aluminum tube incase you bend one.

I put holes and loops for zip ties almost everywhere so I can strap down all my electronics.
For the controller I used a full size Hobbyking KK2 Board but every other Board with 45mm Holes should fit.

I also printed a antenna mount for the FPV antenna and used a extension cable for the VTX

Because I only have one battery I designed the bottom to screw on for more rigidity so the battery is permanently in the Quad.
But I can fly the Quad with one battery almost 45minutes and for the most time its not the only Quad I have ;)

So my last words should be something like "have fun" but if you have questions just ask.

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15% - 20%

Notes:

You may have to sand the frame parts a bit to get a snug fit.
I printed all parts with 15% Infill and covered the main frame parts with a brush in acetone to get the layers fused together.
It survived a few crashes but i usually have some spare parts with me.

description.text:
Hi there!

This is my fist "official" little project, so please be patient if
something goes wrong. I did some other things before and will add
them here too, but I still consider myself as a noob. :)

I recently got a free cabinet which perfectly fits my 3D Printer.
It also had a compartment for mounting filament rolls. All I needed
were proper mounts for the axles.

Requirements:

1 10mm (or smaller) axle and two matching nuts per roll to mount.
The length should be at least 10-12mm shorter than the space you
want to mount it between, as the axle mount base plate is 5mm
thick and you need one on each side.

4 4mm screws for wood mounting to fixate the axle holder.

1 Spool holder

The spool holder itself is a remix of a great and simple design I found
on thingiverse. There are probably tons of great spool adapters around,
so just pick one that fits on your axle.

I used this one before with the original holder that came with the printer
and I liked it a lot, so I kept it with some modifications.

It was required increase the axle diameter as I had tons of spare 10mm
axles, added some additional material to increase stability with the new
diameter and removed the threading as it would cause problems using it
the way I do now.

I will add the remix here later on.

If you like this let me know.

Happy Printing.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The infill should not be to low, as - depending on the spools - there is at least 1/2 Kilo on each mount.
toothbrush, toothpaste and razor holder.

comments.text: I quitelike the simple design. Unfortunately the two curved tabs on the front broke off very easily, and appeared a little flimsy, especially given the work required to remove all the printed support just behind them. I would imagine the tabs could be easily strengthened, perhaps by extending the front of the unit underneath the tabs to enable the tabs to be slightly thicker and have a greater support at their base?  Thanks for your time and efforts.
comments.author: Chookies

comments.text: what slicing software and material are you using? I've never really had an issue with removing the support but I've only used PLA or similar. If you have an issue with the tabs I can make you one with slightly thicker front tabs if you need them.
comments.author: Chookies

comments.text:
Thankyou for the kind offer. I ended up printing a slightly different thingi which has worked out well for me. The material I used was PLA+, and I used Ultimaker Cura as a slicing software. The unit was printed standing right way up. I think a slightly thicker front lip would strengthen the unit for sure, especially as it would be fairly easy to extrude the base out a little further and pull the thickness of the tabs. I'm guessing that would give added strength, without taking away from your nice design. Thanks once again for all of your efforts.
Kind regards, Chookies.

description.text:
This is the JamSentry. A way of detecting and alerting the user to printer Jams and Filament runout conditions. It does not require changes to the printer Firmware. With slight modifications to the G-Code sender it can automatically pause the print when a Jam or Filament runout is detected. It can also emulate a filament runout sensor and trigger the printer to stop via a control signal.

It should work on just about any type of FDM printer and extruder mechanism including dual extruder devices. Due to slightly different tolerances, there are versions for 1.75mm and 3mm filament.

Information on how it works and how to make one can be found at https://robogardens.com/?p=2220

title: Geeetech Prusa I3 ProB Reverse Z-axis (real Z wobble fix)

description.text:
Reverse Z-axis motor mounts

Update 170831: This mod is WIP, I've accidentally got some unwanted Z-backlash that I'm currently tracing, I suspect it's the aluminium-spring-couplers

This mod reverses the position of your z-axis motors in order to let gravity lend a hand for stabilisation as opposed to the stock configuration where the weight of the x-axis actually amplifies the wobbliness.

Here's a somewhat relevant discussion on the subject: https://www.reddit.com/r/Reprap/comments/1xflhl/z_axis_motors_above_or_below/

There's a lot of other excellent solutions out there but some of them introduce backlash.

This solution utilizes only the stock parts and does not introduce any extra backlash , and I recommend using the stock nuts if possible. And worth mentioning is that this modification was surprisingly dead easy to assemble.

Just move your locknuts from the top of the smoothroods to the bottom instead and the rest of the assembly should fall into place by itself.

I almost forgot; You will also need to update your firmware configuration and invert your Z-axis direction.
If you're using marlin then make the following change: 

//Configuration.h

#define INVERT_Z_DIR false        // <-- invert to `true`

comments.text: Real ? NO ! just reduce it  at the lower layers and less as it goes up.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Hah it's you, don't know if i should be honoured or afraid but let me just clarify the "Real"-keyword in a calm and rational way.
I've seen your solution prior to designing this top-bracket, it's a decent solution but not quite what I wanted.
I'd say that both variants are successfull in suspending the x-carriage and relieving the compression from the screws.
Both variants have exactly the same problem that any uneven/skewed parts on the Z-axis will be more pronounced at higher Z-values, basically were just turning the z-axis upside down so instead of getting all the banding in the first layers of our prints we'll get 'em in the last if your prints are high enough. I'd say it's a fair tradeoff as opposed to free-floating nut designs which are also excellent wobble dampeners but sadly introduce backlash that is a no-go if you're using G29-auto-leveling.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
In my solution, the lead screws can't introduce wobble. they hang freely. In yours, it may, unless the motor, the nut and the lower bearings are perfectly aligned. Difficult on such machine and it requires a perfect coupler. A metal, self centering one. The plastic coupler you show is a copy but can't be made to the right specs. A flexible coupler like here is of course bad as it is flexible, vertically too !!! Normally the Z smooth rods are there to prevent wobble but they have so much play !
Furthermore, my set up simplifies and get rid of the out of synch Z steppers.
Has worked fine for a year and now I simplified it further by removing one Z rod (The LM died and I didn't want to buy an other one). Could work with just two lead screws but of better quality and bigger.

title: CL-260 173mm x 17mm COB LED Strip Misumi 2020 Mount

description.text:
This is a COB LED Mount for the 173mm x 17 mm LED Strips that i have found at the german Ebay in a 4 pack from China, there where sold as "Tagfahrlicht" LEDs for cars...

I tried a several other bracktes that are here on Thingiverse but none had the fit I wanted
so I made this one...

It is designed to fit on the 2020 Profiles with M3 Screws and T-nuts.
Also there are 2.6mm square holes for the cables at both ends, because you can daisychain them with
their powerlines.

The whole bracket size is 225mm L x 20mm W x 25mm H and the angle for the LED is 45°
the size of the LEDs I used is with thier aloy housing is 173mm x 17mm x 2.8mm

The LEDs hold in there by sliding them in, so first push the cables trough the holders and then slide one side complete in then align the cables and slide the Led to the center and thats it... in my case thay fited perfectly but maybe you have to scale them a bit.

If you liked it please share a picture of your make.

title: rc boat rudder - updated - L10-50mm, H40-60mm

description.text:
Steering rudder for small boats like LRP Deep Blue One. I made this one to costumize my Deep Blue One and test a improved steering layout with 2 angled rudders to allow better steering. It can also be used as a single rudder for small 3d printed boat projects.
The rudder blade have to be printed 2 times, one of them mirrored and then glued together. Since these are small and thin parts, they should be printed with max. 0.15mm layer thickness and maybe a nozzle smaller than 0.4mm if possible.

The videos are showing the standard rudder on my boat, but it is mounted on the right side because I have changed the prop. The steering don't work so well anymore, so I made this custom thing. A video which shows the boat driving with the new parts will come soon.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Compact GT2 / 2GT belt clamp FPLC Biomaker

description.text:
I needed to clamp a GT2 / 2GT belt for a custom SCARA design, with some tight spots. Most clamps don't run past a sprocket, or tend to slip if they do.

I was inspired by Idegraf's design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1247615), but needed something more compact - hence this design.

There are three versions - each one consits of a top & bottom part.

Slim: has a 0.4 mm top layer, which affects the robustness somewhat.
Thick: has a 1 mm top layer, if thickness is less of a concern & robustness essential.
Staple: slightly different design, with the two pins being replaces by cutouts for two standard office staples. Just pushthem through the two halves once assembled.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Align the models with the pins / holes facing upwards. I printed mine with 2mm walls and 100% infill, but there is probably some leeway. Slower printing (20-30mm/min) will result in nicer printed teeth, and probably better grip on the belt.

If space is less of a concern: the design gets significantly more robust with a thicker top/bottom layer in the model (here only 0.4mm) - will upload a suitable file if requested.

description.text:
Eachine VTX03 cover.

The VTX03 and ATX03 are very cheap - see https://www.banggood.com/Eachine-VTX03-Super-Mini-5_8G-72CH-025mW50mw200mW-Switchable-FPV-Transmitter-p-1114206.html and offer 25mW as well as 200mW and a heap of frequencies to fly on. Problem is the lightweight and small size makes it difficult to mount - so why not stick it on one of your standoffs connecting the top plate?

This design fits perfect on the rear of a RCX130CF frame, with the standoff at the rear being perfect for the stock antenna to fit through.

With some thought, you could use a normal UFL to SMA adaptor and mount it elsewhere safely with a proper antenna.

description.text:
This is a direct download of Gandalf The White Staff by jamundsen, edited to remove the inner portion, allowing for printing in two materials or two colors or any combination of the two. Once the inner portion is printed, it's unlikely to be easily inserted. The taller outer portion has been sliced close to the halfway point, allowing printing on smaller printers, but also allowing the inner portion to be placed before gluing it all together.

I've included the full height outside portion for those who would print with a flexible filament or want to try to squeeze the inside part through the opening. Also included is jamundsen's original staff base. The original Thingiverse post has a file with "repaired" in the file name, identical to this part, but Meshmixer shows no defects with this item.

The outer portion tubular segments are tubular in construction. As a result, the sliced portion created sets of rings, rather than a solid circular cross-section. I didn't see any reason to edit those to have flat surfaces, as the three "corners" provide sufficient foundation for gluing the parts together. Rafts or brims may be necessary to get a good bond on the build plate for the circles, however, as the wall thickness is small.

Notes:

I didn't print it, just edited it by request

description.text:
Baby_Brownie_Special.stl is a full size digital copy of Kokak's little camera; first manufactured in 1938. More information is available at the camerapedia wikia -
camerapedia.wikia.com/wiki/Kodak_Baby_Brownie_Special The Baby Brownie Special is made of bakelite and has a black reflective surface; properties that the directions for 123D Catch suggest be avoided. The camera was dipped in a dilute mixture of water and fine flour. When the mixture dried it left a thin crazed white coat that was easily handed by the program. The "Piggy Bank" is a hollow version with a slit in the top and fittings for a plug in the base: BB_piggy_bank.stl and piggy_bank_plug.stl.
The prongs on the plug overhang and can either be cleaned with a file or the plug can be printed with external support. Some cleaning of the slot that holds the prongs might also be necessary.

description.text:
This spice carousel is geared to its neighbors so that when you rotate one carousel, you rotate them all. It makes searching for the right spice quick and efficient. Each 150mm carousel holds 6 standard spice jars. Link as many together as you like. This utilizes my One Piece Lazy Susan (file included here), that requires 75 6mm dia. airsoft pellets (BBs) for bearing balls.

Watch: https://youtu.be/p1dUTLv7L1o

Printer:

UDIO

Resolution:

0.2mm

After printing, run a bit of sandpaper in the ball channels to smooth out any lumps. Then just snap the airsoft pellets into the ball channel on the turntable. After snapping the ring onto the turntable, if it feels a little loose, you may want to glue it in place with a few drops of superglue. Connect the bases using the links in whatever pattern you like and then just set the turntables on top of each of the bases.

description.text:
With fall in the air, the urge to leave the beach and start working on electronics is starting to itch so to scratch it by developing an Arduino Prototyping Jig. Now I had already created a re-mix as a starter, then got thinking, what about the Nano and SainSmart relays? What about also expanding it from 20x20 maker rail to 20x40 for more stability so that is what I did! As my inspiration for this design came while sitting at my workbench as I faced the project from a "forward" angle and not top down. This made it uncomfortable to work with as all the pins as they were hard to see so figured why not tilt everything on a 30 degree angle so its easy to see? Well here we are and will keep adding to the collection so check back on a regular basis!

Maker Rail:
http://diy3dtech.com/maker-rail/

1-1/2-Inch Surface Grip Adhesive Non Slip Pads:
http://amzn.to/2xJuOeu

M3 Nut and Bolt Section:
http://diy3dtech.com/m3-nuts-and-bolts/

Arduino Uno Boards:
http://diy3dtech.com/arduino-uno-boards/

SainSmart Rely Boards:
http://diy3dtech.com/sainsmart-relay-boards/

Arduino Nano Boards
http://diy3dtech.com/arduino-nano-boards/

Arduino Nano Screw Terminal Shields:
http://diy3dtech.com/arduino-nano-screw-terminal-expansion-board/

Major Favor: if you make one of these please post a MAKE and share it with the community :-) .

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

Printer:

Any Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 or better

Infill:

20% (or abouts)

Notes:

The Nano and SainSmart board print on their side with support everywhere where as the Uno version prints flat on the bed with no support. All of the Magic nut things, legs, and standoffs all print as is without supports...

print_settings.Notes:: A thimble for a rope eye for low load applications, to protect rope against chafe.

description.text:
I needed a thimble for my anchor mooring to protect the mooring rope eye from chafe from the shackle. Barnacles grow on the rope, shackles corrode, and over a period of time can wear out the anchor line. This also has the advantage of being non-conductive for long term salt water applications.

Print in nylon for strength, or ABS for economy.  Strength is dependent on the number of layers, and the fill percentage.  I used enough layers to print a solid unit.  Print flat with no support.  On the upper outer curve where the overhang exceeds 45 degrees, slow print speed and/or use cooling for these layers only.  If using ABS, finish with acetone vapour bath to improve layer bonding, strength  and surface finish.

LulzBot

Printer:

Medium

title: Tri - V tail multi rotor XBS

description.text:
Based on my printable tri copter X bow http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227974
I had a few requests for a simple boom version and wanted to upgrade my X525 quad to a V-tail
This is based on the X 525 booms that are 12.7 mm square booms so should fit stock US 1/2 inch wood booms as well
Can be configured as a Tri or V tail copter
Designed around the KK 2.0 control board
Update March 15> Added a standard "flat" motor base for 10mm booms and and adapted version of my pivot mechanism also for 10mm booms. The other parts for the pivot can be found at the Xbow tri copter ( link above)
Update 17 Feb> Added some 10mm versions of spacers and rear motor mounts to suit 10mm square booms.
For people wanting folding front arms i've added a V2 base plate with a simple latch system
Update > added some 40deg motor mounts for the V tail
If you like this hit the button
Comments always welcome
Enjoy

title: Nest Protect v2 Mount Ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I noticed the non-battery powered nest protect v2 can only be placed on the “power-box” in the ceiling.

Since I could print one, I searched for a suitable 3D printed mount. But sadly didn’t find anything to my liking. Most of them are to high and bulky.

So I designed my own. Goal was a sturdy but mostly hidden mount.

You can use 4 screws, 2 should be enough.

I printed two, mounted both with the two outer holes. Works like a charm!

Prusa

i3 MK2S

No

No

0.2

5%

Print in ABS, 5% infill, 3 perimeters, 5 top layers, 3 bottom

Using slic3er? Disable 'ensure vertical shell thickness'. Not needed for this print, faster print en less stress on your bearings.

title: MiSTer - Case Slim v1.0 (vertical SDRAM mount only)

description.text:
MiSTer - Case Slim v1.0 (vertical SDRAM mount only)

This is a case for the DE10 Nano board. The case was made for the MiSTer FPGA project.

The remix is slimmer and for vertical SDRAM daughter board configuration only.

The case prints well in PLA. Supports are advised for the SD-Card slot section only (extra STL is provided).

There is a spot for a 40x40x10mm fan right above the FPGA chip. It helps with cooling and leaves enough room to place a decent heightened heatsink on top of the FPGA.

-
Update
Updated a small inconsistency in the bottom shell - please re-download.

More info on the case: http://www.atari-forum.com/viewtopic.php?f=101&t=32067

More info on the MiSTer project can be found under these links:

https://github.com/MiSTer-devel/Main_MiSTer/wiki

http://www.atari-forum.com/viewtopic.php?f=101&t=31825

This build requires some electronics knowledge, soldering skills, and an ability to manhandle electronic components without breaking anything.

Working with lead solder is not good for your health because of the fumes, so I turned an old PC case fan into an adjustable fan for my soldering area.

Parts:
92x92x25 mm PC case fan (mine was a Sunon EE92251S2-D130-C99)
Power Switch (I used an NTE 54-517)
Female-to-Female jumper wires (optional)
USB cable
USB power source

Important Notes
I screwed up the initial measurements and didn't realize until everything had printed. I opted not to fix it because it would have made the design bulkier. The workaround is to bend the prongs of the power switch far enough to be out of the way but with enough space that the metal is not touching the plastic or the prongs are not touching each other.

Assuming that anyone who is working on this design has skills in soldering and electronics, so the build should be easy to figure out. If not, let me know.

title: Gocupi gondola with ~30mm diameter pen holder

description.text:
This is another gondola for the Gocupi printed using PLA at 25% infill. This gondola design features a large-diameter (~30mm) pen holder for larger pens like the Sharpie Magnum. I used these sealed bearings: http://www.ebay.com/itm/400947587154
I drilled holes in the ends of the arms and used 2mm nuts/bolts to slip the end clips from the stepper motors over. This makes it easy to remove the gondola from the motors. Small sheet-metal screws were used to screw the servo motor into the bottom holder. The two thin rings are spacers to separate the bearings from the main housing and each other. I'm still working on shims for different sized pens to go into the holder. I'll probably go with some kind of spongy foam.

Summary:

Bought the Anycubic Kossel Linear, and the fixture blocks included matched the glass bed instead of the hot bed. Peaberry's spacers https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1982435 enabled mounting the hot bed, but the link included for the glass bed clips didn't match my hot bed / glass bed combination.
Quickly whipped up my own using FreeCAD.
Each bracket has an elongated slot as a screwhole, so the its position is adjustable along the radius (2mm range)

Measurements of the stuff these clips are designed for:

Hot bed

  • radius: 109.0mm
  • thickness: 2.0mm
  • distance center of screw hole to outer edge: 2mm

Glass bed

  • radius: 100.8mm
  • thickness: 3.3mm (includes the surface sticker shipped in the package)

Screw

  • Type: M3x8 (I had several left from assembling the printer, labelled C06)
  • Screw head radius: 2mm
  • Nut: M3 (also leftovers from assembling)
  • Washer: inner/outer diameter: 3.2mm/7.0mm

If anyone wants the FreeCAD file (could not upload here) for tweaking, feel free to contact me.

title: Articulated Arms Toolset for PCB Workstation (FDM-optimized)

description.text:
This toolset is an evolution of the original set of accessories provided with my "PCB Workstation with Articulated Arms" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279).
It has been specifically designed to get better results from Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printers, so avoiding many common issues caused by this technology.

The main element "Ball and Socket Joint" of the articulated arm, is now much more strong and durable. It is has been designed to be printed orizzontally on the bed so preventing the loosening of the grip and the breakage of the small wings of the spherical socket (see project pictures). Also each adapter has been revisited implementing the new hexagonal socket and fixing a few minor issues.

Please note that in order to get the desired optimal results, each piece must be printed preserving its original orientation (only rotation along z-axis is allowed). Moreover, bridging and support structure generation must be enabled in your slicing software. Rafts are strongly reccomended too.

author: giufini

description.text: This is just a Glass bed holder in case you use multiple beds.

This is a improved version of my former design. The inner diameter has been decreased to improve the clamp strength onto the handle bar, the outer diameter has been decreased as well as a change in the grip pattern to improve ergonomics. Additionally, this design also incorporates a small groove on the inner portion of the grip to allow application of safety wire to increase the interface between the grip and the bar and further prevent the grip from spinning during its lifetime .

How to make the grip using the mold:
Print all three parts of the mold, and purchase a castable silicone. There are many offerings from Smooth-On, which can be purchased from Amazon. My grips used a Smooth-On MoldMax 40, which worked well. Furthermore, to improve tear strength Kevlar pulp can be added to the silicone during the mixing process.

For step by step directions, MakerBot created a great video which can be seen here:
https://www.makerbot.com/professionals/post-processing/silicone-molding-2/

NOTE: Mold release agent does not need to be used, as silicone will have a tough time adhering to the mold.

Basic corner clamp for holding a boxes sides in position when gluing it.

Print 4 of these, put some string/wire/fishing-line around them, use a simple rod as a tourniquet to tighten the line and you've got yourself a box being held at right-angles.

These parts SHOULD print without supports but I haven't experimented with different printers yet. I'd recommend thick walls (3+ layers) and/or internal structure to make these strong.

OpenSCAD file included so you can customise (or customize :) ) the size to your needs.

description.text:
I was getting irritated by the always sagging swivelling towel bar next to my sink in the bathroom. So I decided to design a replacement.

This is a single towel bar that swivels horizontally.
It was designed in OpenSCAD and in printed in neutral PLA.
There is a single 4 mm flathead screw holding it to the wall. The base of the bar is held by a 6 mm bolt and nut.
The base is designed to hold a bolt with allen head. The underside is cut out for the nut to be held in place.

For a bar I used a piece of 10 mm aluminum tubing from the hardware store.
The tube is plugged in front with the plug which is also incorporated in the design.

description.text:
Nema 23 stepper rear cover with db9 female plug and 50mm cooling fan holder.

Instructions:

Cut the stepper cable with approximately 100 mm, pass the wires through the inside of the case and weld them to the db9 plug.
Also connect the two fan wires to the db9 plug and mount in the hole with two M3 screws.
Adjust the excess wires and screw the cover on the motor with 4 more M3 screws.
All to give a cleaner and more professional look to our projects.

description.text:
Basic lightweight servo mount holding two Tower Pro (or other common 9g Generic) servos side by side.

Bottom is recessed for light weight and a place for dabs of hot glue or epoxy to glue in place.

Printed correctly, the servos should be a snap-in fit but you can add a band of masking tape if you prefer a belt and suspenders approach.

Grenade

UPDATE: added version 6 of Thing #24808
This is version 6 of Thing #24808
Libre Graphics World has a nice write up by Alexandre Prokoudine of this extension at http://libregraphicsworld.org/blog/entry/inkscape-gets-openscad-converter
This Thing is an Inkscape extension to export Inkscape paths to OpenSCAD. There has been at least one prior Thing attempting this, Thing #9376. However, it only handled a small subset of SVG. This extension handles SVG arcs, clones, circles, ellipses, groups, lines, paths, polygons, polylines, rects, and splines. It also follows document transforms as well as viewports. Either an entire document or just the selected portions of a document are processed.
SVG text must first be converted to a path within Inkscape using Inkscape's "Path > Object to Path" menu item.
Note that another approach to importing SVG into OpenSCAD is to save the SVG to DXF from within Inkscape. Then use OpenSCAD's import() function to import the DXF. [Older versions of OpenSCAD used import_dxf().]
Much of the core code in this extension is derived from work done by myself and others while developing the Inkscape driver for the Eggbot.
15 June 2012: Added support for a single level of polygon nesting. I.e., subtract from a polygon the polygons contained within it AND from the same Inkscape path. This works well for most fonts. You can tell Inkscape to combine multiple polygons into a single path by selecting the polygons and then using "Path > Combine". (You do not need to do this for text converted to a path: Inkscape already does the proper combining.)
15 June 2012: Corrected Windows issue with handling of Unix-style file paths.
21 June 2012: Correct a typo in the extension. Would not affect content generated by Inkscape but might have affected SVG content generated elsewhere and loaded into Inkscape.
9 May 2013: Modified the code to remove non alphanumeric characters from the strings used to generate the OpenSCAD module names. Some SVG paths had non alphanumeric characters in their path ids and those ids were being used to generate OpenSCAD module names. OpenSCAD doesn't allow that.
29 May 2013: Corrected an issue whereby the converted could exit with an error when attempting to warn about images embedded in the SVG file or Inkscape drawing. Images are not allowed and the converter cannot convert them. However, it should gracefully warn about the issue and exit normally.
30 May 2013: Fixed a bug in the v4 version.
16 Aug 2013: Possible workaround to Inkscape bug experienced by some users, "terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::logic_error' what(): basic_string::_S_construct null not valid"

Downloading
MAC 10.7 or later users, see the second note in the Notes section! This means Lion, Mt. Lion, and beyond.
Download the paths2openscad-2.zip file from this page. After unzipping that archive, you should have two files: paths2openscad.py and paths2openscad.inx .
Installing
Once you have downloaded paths2openscad.zip, open the zip file and place its contents in your local Inkscape extension folder,
~/.config/inkscape/extensions/
on Linux and OS X. On Windows systems, you can place them directly into the Inkscape extension directory. For example, if Inkscape is installed in C:/Program Files/Inkscape then the extension directory will be C:/Program Files/Inkscape/share/extensions.
Once you have placed the two files in the proper directory, exit and then restart Inkscape. The extension should appear under the "Extensions > Generate from Path" menu as "Paths to OpenSCAD".
Using
To use the extension,
  • You may find it helpful to set your document units to millimeters and the document dimension to millimeters as well as a reasonable document size (e.g., 100 x 100 mm). Do this with the "File > Document Properties" menu item. The document units is in the upper part of the dialog box while the document dimensions are near the bottom of that same box.
  • To see what the extension sees, set Inkscape's display mode to "outline". This is done with the "Display Mode" item of the "View" menu.
  • Next ensure that within Inkscape, the desired objects have been converted to paths. Use the "Path > Object to Path" menu item to convert objects such as text to paths.
  • Select the desired objects to generate an OpenSCAD program for. If you wish to generate a program for the entire document, then select nothing (i.e., "Edit > Deselect").
  • From the "Extensions" menu, select "Generate from Path > Paths to OpenSCAD".
  • In the dialog window which appears, enter the name of the output file to generate. (Windows users: the "~" notation indicates that the file goes into your "Document and Settings" folder.) You can also enter a extrusion height and a smoothing parameter. For most purposes, a smoothing parameter of 0.2 is sufficient. If your paths have lots of tight, twisty curves which are described using arcs, circles, ellipses, or other SVG elements which aren't collections of straight line segments, then you may want to use a smaller value.
  • Click the "Apply" button. A pop-up window will appear while the extension is running and will then disappear when it is done running. After the extension is done running, you can click the "Close" button to dismiss the extension's dialog window. If an error occurs, you will see an error window appear when the extension is running.
  • From OpenSCAD, open the output file you generated with the extension and render it.
    Limitations
    If you wish to build solids involving subtracting one polygon from another, be sure to combine the two polygons into a single path: select the polygons and then combine them with "Path > Combine". Only a single level of nesting is handled at present. You do not need to do this for text converted to a path: Inkscape already does the proper combining.
    I have seen a few complex, but legitimate polygons, compile and render with F5 but not with F6 in OpenSCAD. They instead trigger some internal error detection code in OpenSCAD.
    Notes
  • The sample .svg, .stl, and .scad files serve as examples: you do not need to download them to use this Inkscape extension. You only need the .zip file.
  • OS X Lion (10.7) and Mt. Lion (10.8) users need a "patch" to allow Inkscape extensions to work correctly. This is a general Inkscape issue and not specific to this extension. At issue is the lack of a Python package, lxml, which Inkscape extensions use to read (parse) SVG files. Install the patch from https://code.google.com/p/eggbotcode/downloads/detail?name=EggBot2.3.1.r4s.zip . This will also give you Eggbot extensions, many of which I wrote. (An Eggbot is a cool pen plotter for plotting on Eggs.)

comments.author: dnewman

comments.text: On Linux and OS X, I believe what Inkscape does is fork/exec the python script but likely with some choice environment variables defined.  I don't know if it's piping the input/output to the process or what exactly.  But if you look at the tail end of the script, you can see it has code for when it's running as main().  And it does import a number of modules from Inkscape's extensions/ directory so that has to somehow be in Python's search path for importing modules.  (Likely, the forked process has that as its current working directory.)  Unfortunately, the last time I looked (two years ago?), there was no Inkscape documentation on how extensions are run or what their expected run-time environment is.

comments.text: Hi, I've had a scaling issue with the plugin; maybe you can spot where I went wrong from my description or maybe it's a bug. See here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:169068http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: Chinasaur

comments.text: You need to fix your SVG to have units or correct units.  SVG files should specify the units used (cm, ft, in, m, mm, pc, or pt) and if no units are specified then user units are assumed as per the SVG specification. Moreover 1 user unit is defined to be 1px.  Further, the conversion from px to mm is 90px to 25.4 mm.  (More precisely, 90px is defined to be 1inch.)  So, if things are scaled improperly, the issue is likely with your SVG and you need to correct the usage of units in your SVG file.
comments.author: Chinasaur

comments.text: I'll look into the SVG.  Do you have thoughts on why I would end up with 72 units / inch being the correct scale instead of 90?
comments.author: dnewman

comments.text: Whatever software you used to create the SVG must have decided to use 72 units / inch.  It should have, using standardized SVG, specified that it was using units of printer's points, pt, which are 72 pt to 1 inch.  Looks as though it didn't, or there's a bug in the openscad converter which isn't handling the unit specification correctly.

comments.text: Is there a summary somewhere of how this approach compares to the Export DXF method?
comments.author: Chinasaur

comments.text: No.  But the obvious difference is that this approach puts out a format from which a 3D model in STL, OFF, DXF, or CSG can be saved: open the .scad file in OpenSCAD, render it, and then write as a 3D model.  If you produce DXF from Inkscape, then you only have a 2D rendering in DXF.  You may then be able to extrude that in SolidWorks or similar.

comments.text: I am using inkscape 0.48 on Ubuntu 13.04; I have downloaded v3 of the perl script and inx file and placed it in ~/.config/inkscape/extensions. Every time I run the script I get an internal error. Running from the shell shows the following additional information. All other scripts work fine. Can you advise please?
comments.author: sgparry

comments.text: That's an error from Inkscape and C++.  The extension itself is Python code.  If it was a problem with the extension code, you'd see a Python error and not a C++ error.  Your issue is with Inkscape proper and you need to bring it up on an Inkscape forum.  It may be that the extension is not properly installed (e.g., permissions) or some other problem. But this is not the extension itself.  The extension doesn't even provide output which Inkscape reads back.  Which is to say, it's not even possible for the extension to be providing incorrect output back to Inkscape.
comments.author: sgparry

comments.text: I had the same problem, but finally found a solution after some googling: inkscape does not seem to like empty _param elements in the .inx extension descriptor. After removing the empty _param element with name="footer" the extension works fine.

comments.text: Nice plugin, but I keep having inkscape crash on me when I am trying to use it on a particular SVG. Any Advice?
comments.author: ErroneousBosch

comments.text: That's a bug in Inkscape then.  Extensions do not run within Inkscape.  Inkscape writes the SVG to a temporary file and then Inkscape launches a separate process -- concurrently runs another program as though that program is another user.  That separate process runs Python and executes the extension which reads in the SVG and then writes it back out again.  Inkscape waits for that separate process to finish and then reads back in the SVG output by the separate process.  If Inkscape is then dying, then Inkscape has a bug of some sort.  While it's possible that the extension is putting out SVG which isn't what Inkscape wants to see (and may even be bad SVG), Inkscape should not crash.  Instead it should report an error message.
comments.author: ErroneousBosch

title: Customizable Plate Bracket for Aluminium Extrusion Profiles (Misumi 2020, 2040, 4040, ...)

description.text:
This is a customizable thing that allows you to create and print aluminum extrusion plate brackets for different types and sizes of extrusion profiles.

I've also added the 21 brackets for 2020 and for the short side of the 2040 profile as .stl files.

If you need some hammer nuts with a good value for money, I can highly recommend these ones: hammer nuts
I used the Drillpro M5 hammer nuts for my AM8.
They also offer some cheap 2020 aluminium extrusion profiles

This thing was mentioned on hackaday: https://hackaday.com/2017/12/16/if-3d-printer-then-custom-aluminum-extrusion-brackets/

Aluminium Extrusion Series

This is part of my Aluminium Extrusions series. Follow me, if you want to be informed about a new part of this series!

Customizable Settings

Use the Customizer or OpenSCAD to create your own customized set of brackets.

You only need to set these few parameters to get all the 21 brackets automatically:

  • width of mounting side of the extrusion profile (20mm for 2020 profile)
  • length and thickness of the bracket
  • number of rails (2020 has 1, 2040 has 1 and 2 rails)
  • screw hole settings

You can also use the OpenSCAD file as a library (e.g. if you want create a whole printer in OpenSCAD). Check out the description in the head of the file.

How to support me?

Do you like my things and do you want to support me? You can use these links if you want to buy something. This helps me doing more things. Thanks!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/ZXgx3A
Gearbest: https://goo.gl/FfE59f
Aliexpress: https://goo.gl/bQLi15

Anet A8

No

No

author: mightynozzle

description.text:
This is a walking robot controlled by a Parallax Propeller based Activity Board from Parallax. Got idea from Zowi and Otto (see below). Uses Parallax Ping ultrasound distance sensor (for eyes). Uses four HXT12K servos.

There are two versions of head and body. Only difference is with or without nibs that let you attach Lego Duplo bricks.

Code for controller is posted in Propeller forum here:
http://forums.parallax.com/discussion/167218

See it walking here: http://youtube.com/watch?v=edzKARoYnkg

Printer:

DaVinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30% to 90%

Notes:

Legs probably need at least 50% infill.
Orient part to minimize supports.
Used low density supports.
Used ABS.

Remove all supports after printing.
May need file to remove supports fully from legs so that servo can seat.
Do not over clean eyes so that Ping module is held in tight.

Parts Hardware and tools

HXT12K servos are from HobbyKing.com, need at least 4.
Other servos might work if they come with a similar arm.
Screws are #4-40 and at least 3/4" long.
MCU board is Parallax Propeller based Activity Board from Parallax.com
5-cell battery holder is also from Parallax.com
(5-cells is good for NiMh batteries, 4-cells good for alkaline)

You'll also need a Ping distance sensor (for the eyes, not shown) also from Parallax.com

You only need one body and one head. You can pick with or without nibs for Duplo bricks.

Left and right legs are actually identical.

Here are the tools I used. Glue is good for in case you break the printed parts. Step1: Leg Servos

Hardest part of assembly is getting nuts onto screws...

Drop in and bolt down leg servos. There are slots in the back side to help get the nuts on. Getting all the nuts on can be hard. I only used two bolts for each servo. Step2: Legs Use a servo arm to center servo so that middle position points back as shown. Put servo arms into legs. You don't need glue, but I put a dab in there anyway. Attach legs to body as shown and tighten servo screws. Step3: Foot Servos Make sure servos can fit into position without force. You may need to file the opening a bit to remove support material. Use the glue if leg plastic cracks. Use a file, if you need to so that servo goes in without force. Otherwise, you may crack the leg. If it cracks, use the glue. Only attach one bolt and leave nut loose so that servo can tilt back as shown. We need to slide foot over the servo horn later. Use servo arm to center servo as shown. Then, turn servo all the way to the side as shown. Step4: Feet Now, can slide foot into position. Be careful not to use too much force or foot will break. If it breaks, use the glue to fix it. Now, install and tighten servo screws. Then, attach servo arm and screw it in. Thread servo wire through leg and into slots in body. Repeat for other side. Step5: Add Activity Board Install the battery pack. Rubber band helps keep the batteries in place. Use 5-cells for NiMH and 4-cells for alkaline batteries. Drop in the Parallax Propeller Activity board. Little nibs on the edges clip the board in place. Change jumpers from 5V to VIN for two sets of headers so that the 4 servos get full power. Record which servo is connected where. The orange wire should be on the outside. Install the Ping sensor. Do not clean holes to well so that friction holds it in place. Connect Ping, but make sure jumper is set for 5V, not VIN like for the servos !!! Power on. Program servos to go to center position. Put on head Wires need to be toward the center so they clear All done, now need to tweak servo center position in software. All centered. USB cable connects through hole in head. Ready to go! One version of body and head lets you attach blocks...

Ideas from Zowi and Otto

More or less a copy of Zowi and Otto:

Zowi: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:747010

Otto: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1568652

Built from scratch in SolidWorks using the servos that I had : hexTronik HX12K, a low cost all metal servo with the right kind of horn.

title: The BEST 3030 corners. Single and dual.

description.text:
Why another corner ...

I had trouble finding perfect 3030 corners. Some were not able to make the hammer nut lock properly to the frame, since the corner was in the way.

There is also a 2020 version:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2502931

Variants

  • Single corner
  • Dual corner with long skirt (covering the profiles)
  • Dual corner with short skirt (easier printing)

Features:

  • 5.2mm holes (for M5 screws, 10mm)
  • A 10mm gap for the screw cap to fall in
  • A 11mm gap on the extrusion side for the hammer nut to fall in and be able to rotate.
  • Two extensions on the extrusion sides to fall in the extrusion rail. (Nice and tight)
  • 6mm holes in the sides for additional mounting or cable-ties
  • The dual version is perfect for having it mounted on corners. Instead of two seperate corners you have one, which make sure they are perfectly aligned and the corner will be a lot more sturdy.

I'm using these for my HyperCube, and they are rock solid. I printed them with the following configuration:

  • Material: PETG
  • Wall lines: 6 (I don't want to have infill on the smaller walls)
  • Top and bottom layers: 4
  • Infill: 50%
  • Layer height: 0.3 (Lower is better, but this gives me already a powerful result)

More from this collection

2020 profile feet
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2503710

The BEST 2020 corners. Single and dual.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2502931

title: Hexagonal LED Lamp with USB chargeable 18650 battery

description.text:
So this is my first project I published at thingiverse.
I am new to 3d-printing, but I am very happy with this design and the printing results.

The lamp is made of four printed parts (body, inlay, diffusor and the holder for TP4056 chrging circuit).
With the built-in USB charging circuit with overcharge- ond overdischarge-protection I found at ebay and the 18650 battery, the lamp is very usefull for illuminating Your next garden party, camping tour or simply for being used as a night light. Depending on the battery capacity You choose, this light will work for dozens of hours before it needs to be recharged, using a standard 1 Amp USB charger.

You will only need a couple of additional hardware parts:
One 18650 rechargeable Lithium Battery (snaps into the body)
One TP4056 charging circuit (I ordered 5 pieces at ebay for 3 bucks)
One LED of Your choice. I recommend using a straw-headed power LED.
One suitable resistor for the LED.
One standard 20mm (circular) or 13x19mm (rectangular) rocker switch. If You use a 3-position-switch (On-Off-On), you may use 2 different resistors for dimmed and full light output.
Some pieces of wire to solder everything together and two stripes of copper or something suitable for contacting the battery.

The circuit holder was originally designed by Edued and fits perfectly for my lamp (thanks a lot!) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2154115
I made little changes in design: cut-out for charging LEDs, so that the charging status is visible through the diffusor, if You print the inlay with transparent material.

I uploaded two versions of the body with different cut-outs für the rocker switch: one for 20mm circular switch and the other for 13mm by 19mm rectangular switch.
For the diffusor I designed a short and a long version.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Everything is printable with no supports.
Body and TP4056 holder I printed in PLA.
For the diffusor and inlay I used transparent PETG. I think any white filament will do as well.
Everything snap-fits together. You will need no glue, except for the battery contacts (I glued-in two copper-strips).
I used Fusion360 for designing the components and exporting to STL

A housing for use with a Raspberry Pi as well as the Adafruit PiPlate Character LCD Keypad (newer version with buttons on right). This is a popular setup for use with Net-Booting of a Sega NAOMI, NAOMI2, Chihiro or Tri-Force arcade boards with the Pi-Force Tools or NaoPi software.

Keep the electronics protected while also providing a clean utilitarian look Designed for easy assembly with no fasteners and no tools required.

the "pi1" parts are for the discontinued Pi 1 Model B, the "pi2" parts are for the newer Pi1 B+, Pi2, and Pi3 versions. the buttons are the same for both versions.

description.text:
This is a OnePlus One dock that sticks to any flat surface.

I've always liked having docks for my devices but I hate picking up the device only to find the dock has come with it.
This dock uses one of the small lever action suction cups from Harbor Freight to hold the dock securely to whatever surface you want. There is also a cable track built into the base for routing the cable through to the back of the dock.

A cloth covered USB cable was used though most any cable should work, I found mine at the dollar store. The rubber on the micro end requires a little bit of trimming for a snug fit. The cable was glued in place with epoxy. After that the suction cup is added which also helps to hide the wire.
For a truly off the shelf look you can sand and paint the piece as well as add a piece of felt to the base with a hole for the suction cup to pass through.

Harbor Freight Suction Cup with Quick Release

Rough print and finished piece pictures to follow.

Inspired by the works of both jtenkely and AbbyJones
Integrated Suction Cup Glass Mount
Bracket for Polargraph Stepper Motor by jtenkely

OnePlus One Car Mount
by AbbyJones

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.175mm

Infill:

25%

Holes for screws are shorter, they are 4 instead of 2 and they have only 50% engagement, so it shouldn't split the print. And the screws do not go through the whole model, just in case the increased diameters will not cause bad prints on the anti back slash side.

Printing from side causes the nut gap bridge to be smaller, and has a bit better chance to bridge it perfectly.

The center hole for the spring is increased to allow smoother spring insertion. The whole assembly is centered which should cause issues with interference if you have small nema motor.

title: VW New Beetle Spare Tire Screw Knob

description.text:
Note: the original file will need to have the bolt pressed in with a vise. The wider one should work as described below.

This is the knob that holds down the spare tire in a new beetle. I'm not sure about the years this will work on, but mine's an '04, so probably at least '98 to '04? The knob has a tapered wall before the hole for the bolt's head to retain the bolt.

I made this a remix of pavel's knob because they were here first. Had I known their model was online, I probably would have just printed theirs. I like mine better simply because I think it matches the original better and because it's my own. However if this model doesn't work, check out theirs and see if it fits.

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Because of heat in the vehicle, and the fact that it's attached to the frame of the vehicle, you should probably print this in something other than PLA.

If you print with the largest face on the bed and you'll need a little bit of supports in the hole. If you print with the smallest face on the bed and you'll need supports under the whole knob, but you won't need to clean the hole for the bolt's head as carefully.

Remove Supports

Remove the supports, making sure to clean out the wider area under the taper for the head of the bolt. This is where the bolt will actually sit.

Push In Bolt

Seat the bolt in as far as it will go. Don't worry if it doesn't go in all the way.

Seat the Bolt Completely

For the original: Press the bolt in with a spacer and a vice, hammer, or other tool.

For the "wider" file: Screw the bolt partway into the hole for your spare tire and pull up to seat the head below the taper. Alternatively, tighten the bolt until it's pulled into position by the the pressure against the wheel.

Drive Away!

You're now set. Put the tools back into the wheel as usual and fold the carpet back.

title: Modified M2 Easy Access Drive with Leveling Attachment

description.text:
This is a remix of the 'Makergear M2 V4 Easy Access Filament Drive V2' by SCHEMENKE. I expanded the filament path as I had problems with the filament binding in the path. Given that the filament passes through an airspace before passing into the hot end, having a little extra space doesn't strike me as an issue. I have not seen any issues with my printing.

The V4 hot end is spectacular - if you have an M2 and don't have the V4, it is a great upgrade.

I have also included a 'blank pivot' as an OpenSCAD module and a version of the pivot that accepts a AccuRemote Digital Indicator Gauge (available on Amazon) for bed leveling. Also included is a Z Axis Spacer that keeps the stage a centimeter from the tip of the hot end. I typically use the Simplify 3D Bed Leveling tool with manual setpoints adjusted such that the tip of the gauge is over each of the three setscrews and the fourth symmetric location. On starting the leveler, I put the Z Axis spacer in place and to keep the bed from going all the way to the hot end and then take the spacer off during the move to the first setpoint. After leveling, if I have moved the stage much then I adjust the Z Axis set screw to do the final adjustment of hot end clearance from the bed.

I print the pieces in Atomic PETG+CarbonFiber with medium resolution. The PETG with Carbon Fiber is stiff and tough. The gauge fits snugly enough I don't use a bolt to fix it to the pivot but the hole is there should it be necessary.

author: SuperheroDIY

description.text:
This fidget design came to me during a conversation I had with the Mrs about bygone toys I loved as a child. One of which was the He-Man Masters of the Universe ATTAK TRAK vehicle:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EZgh36Jvtwc (Accessed 27/08/17)

I don't know why it popped into my head but I can still remember being amazed by the way the 'wheels' worked. I then decided to try and design a fidget that would encompass the same mechanism as I felt it would lend itself to quite an unusual hand toy.

Since my wife's name is Jo and mine is Sam, I decided to call it the 'JAM fidget'.

The entire print (3 pieces) should take just a few minutes either side of one hour and requires just one bearing. I chose to use an ABEC-11 bearing in mine but only because they were the only ones I had laying around.

Here's a video of it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dLkO2KMYMG8

Anyway, I hope you have fun with it. It would be great to see if this newest version takes off -- if you do like it, please post a 'Made'.

JAM

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

General Notes:

There's really very little to say about assembly. Just bear in mind that the bearing and gear sleeve is an interference fit and will need a fair amount of force to overcome it. Also, be sparing with the superglue -- if not you run the risk of gluing the gear inside to the housing.

Trumpet for Maxbotix XL-EZn range of ultrasonic sensors. These are to protect the sensor from wind and rain when used as part of the Oxford Flood network sensor.   
The cutting template is just a thinner version of the base that can be used to accurately drill and cut the box without damaging the trumpet itself.

Print the trumpet and the cutting template so that you can accurately drill and cut the case. The bolt holes are for 12mm M3 bolts but may need enlarging with a 3mm drill bit.   
The M3 bolts go through the mounting holes in the sensor, through the case and screw into the holes in the trumpet. They should make their own thread and hold it securely.
Comes into Cura pretty small but i designed it to be scaled to 3" round. I am still building my new printer so i cant test print it.

Hi all,

This is a remixed part from the speed tank. The intention is to build a track drive for a toy fire engine. Other than with the speed tank the toy track will get slow engine speed which is more appropriate in indoor toys for kids. In addition, it will get a chassis somewhat like a fire engine and it will be equipped with a water tank and pump.

Some update on this little project.

I am currently trying to fit a standard RC servo as the driving motor. This has some advantages over using a stand-alone brushless motor, number one we don't need a motor controller since that is already coming with the servo, number two the drive speed will be rather slow and therefore more suitable for a toy.

I uploaded and new main drive wheel with a smaller gear, only 40 teeth.

On my remixed part there is no way to tension the chain, in other speed tanks variations I have seen some ways to tension the chain, however, I wanted to keep things simple and therefore I have made a new chain link which is just 2mm longer than the original one. This doesn't make a whole lot of difference while going over the chain wheels and just putting two or three of the longer chain links into the track, I am able to fine-tune the tension to the desired point.
To easily distinguish between the two different chain links I have "stamped" the longer one with an "L". So please be aware, that the one uploaded here is the longer one.

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

Questions - use the comments, send me a message here or on patreon.

title: Razor Scooter Motorcycle Style Throttle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Built this throttle because my little one had a hard time holding the Razor Scooter's throttle on for extended time, before their hand began hurting. I printed both tubes separately standing vertically with openings pointing down and without support on the Prusa i3 using 1,75mm PLA.

Installation Instructions:
First remove the black handle on the scooter, then loosen the allen lock screw on the throttle. Install the plastic inner bushing and re-tighten the throttle in place so that the bushing is fully on the handle bar shaft. Then install the larger throttle tube, taking care to use a flat blade screwdriver to force the rubber throttle inside. No glue is required as this is built as a friction fit and easily undone.

This is a simple 30° Mount for the Shrieker to use with a Runcam Split or Mini.
I wanted to move the camera as far up as possible to reduce the amount of visible propellers in the image.

Use M2x3mm screws (M2x4mm may also be okay, be very careful to not screw them in too far).

Print in TPU. Provides a bit of damping for vibration this way.
